:'''''Great Road''' redirects here. This name sometimes refers to the '''[[East Road]]'''.''
The '''Royal Road''',<ref name=Isen>{{UT|11c}}, first paragraph of the long note</ref> also called the '''Great Road''',<ref>{{UT|Eorl}}</ref> was a major road in the [[Westlands]] that connected [[Fornost Erain]] in the northern kingdom of [[Arnor]] with [[Minas Tirith]] and [[Osgiliath]] in the southern kingdom of [[Gondor]].<ref name=Isen/>

==Course==
[[File:Sage - Great Road.png|thumb|Course of the Great Road (highlighted with red) with its major stops.]]
The Royal Road originally ran from Fornost in Arnor in the far north, southward for hundreds of leagues through [[Eriador]] passing by [[Bree]] (where it crossed the [[East Road|East-West Road]]), on through [[Andrath]] between the [[Barrow-downs]] and the [[South Downs]] and then southeastwards through [[Cardolan]] on long causeways across the fens of [[Minhiriath]] to the bridge<ref name=Glanduin>{{UT|6d}}, discussion of the name ''Glanduin'', first paragraph</ref> over the river [[Greyflood]] at the city of [[Tharbad]].<ref name=Map>{{FR|Map}}</ref>

The road continued southeastwards on a long causeway across the fens on the plains of [[Enedwaith]]<ref name=Glanduin/> and then on the higher land in the north-east and centre of Enedwaith<ref name=Isen/> until it approached the southern end of the [[Misty Mountains]] where it ran eastwards to the [[Fords of Isen]].<ref name=Map/> The part of the Royal Road from Fornost to the Fords of Isen was called the North-South Road or the North Road.<ref>{{FR|Sign}}, p. 150</ref><ref>{{FR|South}}, p. 274</ref><ref name=Greenway>{{HM|UI}}, entry ''Greenway'', p. 31</ref> It is possible that this part was also referred to as the Old South Road.<ref>[[Christopher Tolkien]], [[General Map of Middle-earth]]</ref><ref group=note>From the point of view of Fornost the road primarily runs from the north to the south until the Fords of Isen and then primarily runs to the east, so the name North-South Road or North Road may not have applied to the part of the road east of the Fords of Isen.</ref>

After the Fords of Isen, the road ran through [[Calenardhon]]/[[Rohan]] eastwards for a few miles, then turned southeastwards approaching the [[White Mountains]] and then ran roughly parallel to the White Mountains on their northern side through the [[Westfold]], the [[Eastfold]] and [[Anorien]] to the eastern end of the White Mountains where it entered the [[Rammas Echor]] through its [[Forannest|north gate]].<ref name=Map/> It is possible that the part of the Royal Road road from the Fords of Isen to Minas Tirith was called the [[Great West Road]]<ref>{{RK|Map}}</ref><ref>{{HM|RC}}, entry West Road, p. 892</ref> or the West Road.<ref>{{RK|Debate}}, p. 882</ref><ref group=note>From the point of view of Osgiliath or Minas Tirith the road primarily runs to the west until the Fords of Isen and then primarily runs to the north, so the name Great West Road may not have applied to the part of the road west of the Fords of Isen.</ref>

==History==
The Royal Road had been constructed by the [[Númenóreans]] by the year {{TA|2}}.<ref>{{App|TA}}, entry for the year 2, p. 1085</ref><ref>{{UT|7a}}, note 6, p. 360</ref>

After the spreading of the [[Great Plague]] to Enedwaith and Mihiriath in {{TA|1636}}, Enedwaith began to return to a state of wild fen-lands and the causeways on which the road ran to the Greyflood started to crumble.<ref name=Glanduin/> 

At the end of the Kings in Arnor and Gondor ({{TA|1975}}-{{TA|2050|n}}) and the beginning of the decline of Gondor, the border of Gondor was retreated from the river Greyflood to the river [[Isen]]. The Royal Road in this land ceased to be maintained, and the Bridge of Tharbad became so ruinous that the Greyflood had to be crossed by a dangerous ford<ref name=Isen/> formed by the ruins of the bridge.<ref name=Isen/>

After the [[Fell Winter]] of {{TA|2911}},<ref>{{App|TA}}, entry for the year 2911, p. 1089</ref> in {{TA|2912}} Enedwaith and Minhiriath were devastated by great floods and Tharbad was ruined and deserted.<ref>{{App|TA}}, entry for the year 2912, p. 1089</ref> It is probable that this event caused traffic on the road to decline further.

After it became less used and overgrown by grass the part of the Royal Road from Fornost to the Fords of Isen was called the [[Greenway]] by the Bree-folk.<ref name=Greenway/>

==Other versions of the legendarium==
Only parts of the North-South Road are taken in consideration in the narrative of ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]''. The route is partially seen on the [[General Map of Middle-earth]], which was published with earlier editions of ''The Lord of the Rings'' (and later in [[Pauline Baynes]]'s ''[[A Map of Middle-earth]]''). In those earlier maps, the portion of the road from [[Enedwaith]] to [[Rohan]] is not seen, suggesting that the road was abandoned or ruined after contact and traffic was diminished.

The name '''Great Road''' in the ''[[Unfinished Tales]]'' refers to the road that links Arnor and Gondor, which is drawn without gaps in [[The West of Middle-earth at the End of the Third Age|the map accompanying the book]].<ref>{{UT|Map}}</ref> [[Christopher Tolkien]] interpolated the course between Enedwaith and Rohan to restore it on the new map.<ref>{{UT|IMap}}</ref> Confusingly, the name '''Great Road''' in the [[Appendices]] of ''The Lord of the Rings'' refers to the [[East Road]].<ref>{{App|Eriador}}, pp. 1039-40</ref>
